Hey Jeff,

We've had some interesting, extended discussions on bloat in this group:

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/msearch?query=bloat&submit=Search&charset=ISO-8859-1

You'll probably want to look through some of the prior discussions.

As you've brought up, some ways of controlling bloat are to reduce the
add mutation rates, increase the delete mutation rates, and penalize
larger networks. But on this list we've discussed the relative merits
of allowing for some topology to be added that doesn't provide an
immediate benefit, under the assumption that the raw material might be
co-opted for some adaptive purpose later. We'd probably all agree that
there's some happy medium...you don't want your genomes exploding
exponentially in size right out of the gate, but you do want them
growing, in general.

--Derek
